unnormalised: A minor snafu occurred during a recent lecture at IIT Delhi regarding differential calculus. Prof. Sharma apparently mixed up Leibniz's notation with Lagrange's while explaining derivatives. Several students, who were cramming for their MA101 exam, were understandably confused.
normalised: A minor snafu occurred during a recent lecture at I-I-T Delhi regarding differential calculus. Professor Sharma apparently mixed up Leibniz's notation with Lagrange's while explaining derivatives. Several students, who were cramming for their M-A one hundred and one exam, were understandably confused.

unnormalised: "I thought d/dx(f(x)) was the same as f'(x)?", asked Rohan, a 1st-year B.Tech student, during the Q&A session. The Prof, realizing his mistake, quickly backtracked, stating it was just a "momentary lapse in concentration." He further added, "Everyone makes mistakes, even profs like me".
normalised: "I thought d divided by d x of f of x was the same as f prime of x?", asked Rohan, a first year B-Tech student, during the Q-and-A session. The Professor, realizing his mistake, quickly backtracked, stating it was just a "momentary lapse in concentration." He further added, "Everyone makes mistakes, even profs like me".

unnormalised: However, word spread quickly through the IITD WhatsApp groups. One meme showed Prof. Sharma's face photoshopped onto a confused mathematician. Another suggested the lecture should be re-dubbed "Differential Calcu-Oops!".
normalised: However, word spread quickly through the I-I-T-D WhatsApp groups. One meme showed Professor Sharma's face photoshopped onto a confused mathematician. Another suggested the lecture should be re-dubbed "Differential Calcu-Oops!".

unnormalised: This isn't the first time something like this has happened. Last sem, a similar incident occurred in the linear algebra class where the professor accidentally transposed a 3x3 matrix during a crucial step in solving a system of equations. It lead to all the students getting a completely wrong solution in their assignments.

unnormalised: While these incidents can be humorous, they also highlight the pressure on professors at top institutions to deliver flawless lectures consistently. Let’s cut the Prof some slack, it was one mistake out of the 100s of lectures delivered across multiple years.
